Question: Writing String to Text File: :I am saving a log to a .txt file on the sdcard but once there is two lines saved, it overwrites it and starts over?Here is my code: public static String getTimestamp() {    try {        SimpleDateFormat dateFormat = new SimpleDateFormat("MMMdd HH:mm:ss", Locale.getDefault());        String currentTimeStamp = dateFormat.format(new Date()); // Find todays date        return currentTimeStamp;    } catch (Exception e) {        e.printStackTrace();        return null;    }}public static void writeToLog(Context context, String string) {    String text = getTimestamp() + " " + string;    // ONLY SAVES TWO LINES    try {        PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(logFile, true)));        out.println(text);        out.close();    } catch (IOException e) {        Log.d(Constants.APP_NAME, e.toString());    }}As soon as you mount /data in recovery, the log files in /sdcard & /data/media/0 show the full log history but not when the device is powered on

Answer: The issue is that you are using `PrintWriter` with `FileWriter` in append mode (`true`). This will truncate the file every time you open it, so only the last line is kept. Instead, you should use `false` to open the file in normal mode, which will allow you to append to the file. Here is the corrected code:

```java
public static void writeToLog(Context context, String string) {
    String text = getTimestamp() + " " + string;
    try {
        File logFile = new File(Environment.getExternalStorageDirectory(), "log.txt");
        PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(logFile, false)));
        out.println(text);
        out.close();
    } catch (IOException e) {
        Log.d(Constants.APP_NAME, e.toString());
    }
}
```

This code will append to the file, not overwrite it.

Please note that the `Environment.getExternalStorageDirectory()` is deprecated since API 29. You should use `getExternalFilesDir()` or `getExternalFilesDir(null)` instead. Here is the updated code:

```java
public static void writeToLog(Context context, String string) {
    String text = getTimestamp() + " " + string;
    try {
        File logFile = new File(context.getExternalFilesDir(null), "log.txt");
        PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(logFile, false)));
        out.println(text);
        out.close();
    } catch (IOException e) {
        Log.d(Constants.APP_NAME, e.toString());
    }
}
```

This code will append to the file, not overwrite it, and it will work on devices running Android 11 (API level 30) and above.

Please note that writing to external storage requires the `WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` permission. Make sure you have this permission in your manifest file.

```xml
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE" />
```

Also, if you want to write to the external storage, you should request this permission at runtime.
